subject: Re: [junit] Creating own subclass of TestCase as base for tests
msgSnippet: This is just from the hip, but if you re intending to provide new functionality in a similar API, you might consider this: 1. Put your setUp and tearDown
messageBody:
This is just from the hip, but if you're intending to provide new
functionality in a "similar" API, you might consider this:

1. Put your setUp and tearDown code in the TestCase.setUp() and
tearDown() as usual.

2. Declare your setUp() and tearDown() as final.

3. Expose a new overridable method for clients to use.

In general, that's the approach I use when I want to allow subclasses
to add functionality, but fear that they'll "forget" to call super(..).

This, of course, breaks every test currently written for your
framework, and changes your API slightly from the very familiar JUnit
API. As a rebuttal (although I have no opinion either way) it isn't as
though it's a difficult fix since your compiler will tell you
everywhere to do it.

Alternatively, whatever functionality your test classes provide could
simply fail with a useful message if the super.setUp() isn't called.
Catching and reliably reporting a forgotten tearDown() call is tricker,
though.

Hope this helps,

Kevin Klinemeier

--- Martijn Dashorst <yahoogroups@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I'm a maintainer of jWebUnit and we've got a problem with resource
> deallocation when many tests are run (1000+). This is due to the HTTP
>
> driver (WebTester) which is allocated in the constructor (bad policy,
> I
> know) and which is only freed when the TestCase is cleaned up by the
> GC.
>
> Now my question is: how do I allocate/deallocate the HTTP driver
> without
> needing my clients' subclasses to call super.setUp() and
> super.tearDown() in their implementations of setUp()/tearDown().
>
> I was thinking of overriding runBare() in which I allocate the driver
>
> before calling super.runBare(), and in a finally block, I dereference
>
> the driver:
>
> public void runBare() throws Throwable {
> try {
> tester = new WebTester();
> super.runBare();
> } finally {
> tester = null;
> }
> }
>
> This allows subclasses of WebTestCase to override setUp() and
> tearDown()
> without requiring them to call super.setUp()/tearDown().
>
> This is rather risky, for I have no guarantee that runBare() is
> called
> in each environment (ant, Eclipse, IntelliJ, etc).
>
> Creating my own WebTestCase extends Assert implements Test would
> require
> me to implement a lot of code, not just delegation, or am I missing
> something?
>
> I hope you could shed some light on this.
>
> Martijn Dashorst
>
>
